												As a fan of the Spellforce universe and the RTS genre, this edition was an easy purchase. After playing the Order of Dawn and the expansions several times; I got interested in the unique gameplay and the world of Eo. However this game changed the mechanics of the gameplay and the way you play it, for example, you no longer play as a rune warrior in the campaign but instead you’re a Shaikan, possessing dragon blood with similar features to a rune warrior without the power of using the monuments. The gameplay no longer uses the monuments as a headquarters for army and base building, but now you build small towns from which you build your armies, and although I preferred the old gameplay this was also fun. Your heroes now level up with you, allowing further customization. Instead of managing the six nations like in the previous Spellforce, this one has 3 alliances in which you build armies, the Realm, the Pact and the Clans, the Dragon Storm campaign also adds the Shaikan faction. The base building elements are fun to play like the previous game, but some aspects like the resources for the town and army management was superior in the Order of Dawn, they removed the buildings that doubled the resource income and the resources are on average very limited supply, this also presents more of a challenge because your enemies always possess huge amounts of resource deposits near their bases and you can use this to your advantage in some cases but also forces  you into more rushed tactics. The game also feature the Free game mode, allowing further gameplay and also a bit more challenging than the campaign.I enjoyed the Rune warrior gameplay more than the Shaikan, but I still liked this game. There were some issues with the camera bugs in the Shadow Wars campaign, but fortunately the Dragon Storm expansion was free of them.The soundtrack is beautiful and fitting to the Spellforce Universe. The graphics are also some of the most good looking of the real time strategy genre.Overall, it is a good game and a fine sequel with some changes that might not please every gamer but it is a great addition to the universe.

												I really wanted to give this game a positive review and until today I was pretty sure it's going to happen. Let's start by saying, that I've played both main Spell Force games when I was much younger and it was great to remind myself why I enjoyed these games. It's very good combination of rpg and strategy. So why the negative review?Well... First of all, this game is better than the first one. I find it hard to believe that someone without sentiment towards first Spell Force would have a different opinion. Plot is solid, in both games, but Spell Force 2 has better graphic, better music and most importantly, better controls. It's also much better paced. You finally don't feel like you wasting eternity just going from one point on the map to another. It has aged much better that the first game, it's still very enjoyable, you don't get the feeling like the camera or characters movements are clunky. Strategic elements of the game were also improved. The only thing that I've enjoyed better in the first Spell Force was the fact, that it has definitely more freedom in terms of creating your own character.As for Spell Force 2 itself...Pros:+ interesting plot+ original and well done mix between strategy and rpg+ game is truly challenging+ great music+ interesting and useful spells/special abilities that unlocks when you level upCons:- low resolution- lack of truly interesting quests- gaining another level doesn't really feel that rewarding- pretty limited character creation- dialogue scenes are essentially broken - characters not always shows up or does not shows up properly- BUGS.Yeah, I'm sorry, but how can you recommend a game that basically make you feel like you've wasted 16 hours of your life playing it? I am really understanding, I'm not the type of person who gets over frustrated and never wants to play a game after encountering a less or more serious bug. Sure, it's pretty annoying, but if it can be fixed somehow, if I can replay some sequences or just restart the whole mission, I'm still going to do this. So I've encountered few serious, game breaking bugs. Two times restarting missions worked. In other instance, skipping the dialogue was an only way to avoid being literally stuck in the void. And now... Well, now I actually can't finish my quest, because even though I've done everything that was needed to be done, even get a note in journal to go back to the person that is crucial for moving the plot forward... Well, this person does not want to talk to me. At all. There's no scene. No dialogue. Nothing. Replaying the sequence and the whole mission didn't work.Maybe this game works better on older systems (I don't remember having this sort of problems in the past), but with this amount of serious bugs it's not really worth a recommendation. Buy it only if you want to replay it or just remind yourself the whole series.

												After spending 180ish hours beating Spellforce+expansions on hard, I was excited to jump into SF2.  This edition contains the core Spellforce 2 and the first expansion (Dragon Wars).  Overall, I really like the updates they had made to the game.  They worked out a bunch of the issues from the first game (ie. Avatar not attacking, losing units when switching maps, etc.) and made a polished sequel that rivals the first in terms of being enjoyable.GRAPHICS:  9/10 - The game is from 2006 so again, cannot expect much here.  I was pleasantly surprised with the world design and the characters themselves.  For those using a newer system, the FOV console command will be your best friend!  At the start of each level, you'll find your FOV pretty limited.  Do this:  Ctrl + ] to access the console.  Type "UI:SetCameraFOV(1.060)" to back the camera out a bit.  The higher the number, the further out you go.STORY: 10/10 - The Spellforce storyline has really come along since the first game.  You could see them hitting their stride as you went through the expansions of the first game and it continues here.  Really enjoy the story!GAMEPLAY: 9/10 - I personally like the new leveling system as it allows more customization between all characters (not just your avatar).  I wish they would allow full customization for all characters but your fellow party members all follow a certain path with only a few skill points allowed to be distributed by the player (ie. Whisper will go Dual Swords, no matter what).  I understand the need to direct the player towards a healer, tank, etc... but maybe allow for a mode where experienced players can completely customize the skills.  Other than that, the gameplay is smooth and fun.  Quite a bit easier than the first game though.SOUND: 9/10 - Once again, the Spellforce music is great and the voiceover is MUCH better than the original.  Still not perfect, but anything was better than SF1.  Overall, this game is definitely worth picking up!  I spent ~90 hours beating it on the hardest difficulty.

You cannot see the world and cannot therefore order units effectively or interact with quest objects. There is a patch that 'seems' to fix most instances, except the dwarven camp where I needed it to fix it. You can mash the space bar/escape button to rush through/skip dialogue. That seems to avoid the camera bug, but NPC behavior can get wonky, since sometimes (at least once) NPCs might need to spawn or despawn during cutscenes.Another bug where you sacrifice 'light worshippers' and one of them doesn't walk properly. Going into 3rd person and bumping her seems to fix. But readers can see the game is buggy. This is all apparently because of the way they mashed two games together to make the 'Gold Edition'. Reminds me of what I've heard of the Homeworld re-releases: apparently not-breaking code during a copy-paste marathon is harder than it sounds... But I'll go onto the game itself now.The story involves you getting reinforcements to stop an army and save your village/city. So you convince a count to give a letter of recommendation (LoR) to a baron, after saving the count from annihilation. You escort the count's son and some supplies to the baron, who you save from annihilation in return for a letter of recommendation to the king. The count's son escorts you to the king, who says 'no'. But there are others who might rally to the cause, you have to convince them to join and bash through the enemy's fortress from behind, because that is the only way back to the village you're trying to save. Through the attackers' main castle. There's a part where you have to wake a passed-out drunk dwarf. That involves a four-part quest with at least four NPCs. The word that describes this is tedious. Much of the plot is 'we need to go to X' but the only way to X happens to be through Y and Z levels. So out of 20 or so regions, 10 of them are padding and 5 or so more hold MacGuffins. Great.You have armies, including semi-unique 'titan' units, which are as ROFL stomping-forgot your bubblegum-s**t just got real-as you'd expect. But I'd rather have the player become that way, well, eventually. For a little bit. Well, anyhow... The strategy element is kiiinda okay, except the difficulty is very arbitrary and base-building is very formulaic. Example: one mission you need to free captured orcs by beating a human base. Except, for no good reason there are giant spiders attacking your base constantly. And when you beat the humans you get surprised dialogue about 'the spiders are coming', suggesting the spiders should have only started spawning at this point. The game also feels like is was made with the Warcraft 3 map editor, with some voiceovers added.You also get access to different cool races! But how this happens is the previous race that you can finally use with all their units, the race whose territories you just saved from annihilation or lead to impossible victory, they give you the finger and for no good reason your defeated foes now trust you to lead their forces. It's just a little better than "Message from the developers: you're going to play the next part of the game with this new race, starting from the ground up again. Have fun!"There are other gripes, but this is my second REwrite of this review, so I'll leave the smaller things to others.

The insane thing is, after doing some digging, I found out that you CAN in fact save, but only through using the case-sensitive console built into the game. So the game is perfectly capable of saving, but apparently it was too much work to add a friggin save button. This is seriously the laziest thing I have EVER seen in a game from a major developer/publisher, especially since they've had years and years to patch it in. As for the RTS part itself, it's rather simplistic, you build buildings to unlock units and you can make heroes. You can't upgrade any units and the hero skills seem horribly unbalanced. 												The Spellforce series feels like a mish-mash of  Dungeon Seige and the original Warcraft: a shallow party based dungeon delve attached to a shallow strategy game. You control a band of heroes, and sometimes you get a base to build an army of disposable red-shirts. The heroes level up with you and gain skills, the military units are cannon fodder. That's the crux of it; not much depth here. It does, however, create a nice hybrid game in that you don't have to live and die by either your hero build, or your micro-managing skills as a strategy gamer.What Spellforce bills as a feature to make combat easy actually makes it tedious, but the amount of quick control it gives you is worth it. Once you're over the shock of having to click so many times to control your party, you'll find you can quickly dispatch many different units.The story is on rails, so no replay value; but worth the pricetag if you like BOTH Baldur's and Warcraft.
